history.content:
Yes, it should be possible to enroll without having taken CS 70.  I never took 70, then took CS 188 concurrently with Math 55.

As far as preparation goes, Math 55 covers to some degree everything in CS 70 that you would need for 188 (mathematical logic, graphs, discrete probability) but arguably doesn't go into enough depth in the probability, so it would be helpful to study more of that.  I've heard the CS 70 notes are excellent, and Pitman's Probability (used in Stat 134) is also good for this purpose.

children.subject: and i guess beyond that other upperdiv cs classes that require cs 70
Take EECS126. That's the level that will serve you very well.
Thanks for the response about 188, what about 189 (also planning to take stat 134 if relevant)

you can still take 188, there will just be a very steep learning curve for you compared to others who have taken 70. It is a strongly recommended to take 70 before 188 to aid in your success in the class.

Is it possible to take 188 without having taken 70? I looked through alot of posts about taking 70 concurrently and many said it is fine, but what if I don't take it concurrently? Would I still be able to pass? I also don't have any prior exposure to probability

history.content: I want to do a cs&math double major, and was wondering how well a student with only math 55 could do in some of the upperdivs compared to one with cs70. Also, on the berkeley academic guide some classes such as cs 188 don't take math 55, only cs 70. Would I be able to get into those classes with math 55?
history.subject: Math 55 as prereq for upperdivs
